column1: Before 16 December 2021, will the Federal Reserve announce it will reduce its monthly quantitative easing bond buying?
column6: ['Business', 'Finance', 'Economic Policy', 'US Policy']
Resolves today.
According to the financial press the Fed has been telegraphing the beginning of the taper for some time now. See https://www.ft.com/content/8ff2a38e-82d1-429a-935f-a26ace6f7e1d
Sounds like the tapering announcement is expected Wednesday.
They will very likely announce tapering after Wednesday's meeting: https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-business-health-economy-inflation-b9c578a9c296b577954f9747ae420e4e
Australia just tried to taper and it blew up in their face https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/australias-2y-bond-just-blew-after-central-bank-unexpectedly-refused-buy-it
Down a bit to 85 as recent weakening in the economy due to Delta may spook the Fed a bit.
I still think it will happen, but am less certain. [I also think it should happen, but that has no effect whatsoever.]
increasing again on the recent jobless claims: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/weekly-jobless-claims-week-ended-october-16-2021-193313259.html

Reducing due to the GDP now forecast of 0.5% GDP from 1.2%. This is hardly the only indicator that I've seen out there of a coming possible recession, but it is the type of indicator that the FED might actually look at and decide to delay tapering. Also, China has been greatly reducing its treasury purchases and someone has to buy that debt
increasing a bit based on [https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1343769] thanks to @erikbays
increasing on the recent jobless claims

The recently released FOMC minutes state that they are planning on beginning tapering November or December. However, this was before all of the recent bad economic news. A jobs report has come in below expectations, China is having a real estate meltdown that is leaking over to their stock market, our labor force participation rate has declined, and we may have several more weeks of bad economic news with the earnings reports coming out.
China has
Raising to 90% on assumption Jay Powell is nominated. If he is not, will drop the odds.
increasing 5% based on @borisn 's excellent comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1339763
Inflation is above the target 2% rate, and so Tapering will begin after the November 3rd FOMC meeting. Fed chairman Powell signaled this in his September press conference.

Initial jobless claims at a 7 week high on top of all of the other horrible economic data out there. Initial jobless claims are a leading indicator of future economic problems. China is going through a real estate meltdown similar to the layman Brothers meltdown the US had in 2007, which could spill over to the United States. If the Fed didn't announce a tapering before, why would they do it now when the market isn't any better and maybe is even worse? If the Fed has to choose between unemployment and the stock market they will always choose the stock market.

Lowering due the turmoil from the china property market collapse and how it is affecting treasury prices. I find it amusing that now that time has passed, and one Fed meeting has passed where the Fed didn't announce anything, and the crowd certainty has gone up instead of down.

“If progress continues broadly as expected, the Committee judges that a moderation in the pace of asset purchases may soon be warranted,” the FOMC’s post-meeting statement said. Respondents to a recent CNBC survey said they expect tapering of bond purchases to be announced in November and begin in December. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/22/federal-reserve-holds-interest-rates-steady-says-tapering-of-bond-buying-coming-soon.html
After last month's conference the commentary strongly indicated that at the next meeting (December) the Fed would announce tapering. I'll peg the probability at 85%

https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-tees-up-taper-and-signals-rate-rises-possible-next-year-11632333617?mod=hp_lead_pos3 In recent years the Fed has begun saying what they mean, or at least what they mean at the moment, and is less often opaque and Delphic. Stay tuned.
All ships rise with the tide: https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/with-focus-taper-five-questions-fed-2021-09-20/

The labordata from august was weaker than expectet and there are signs of lower momentum in the economy. But the focus on reducing or not reducing the tapering program is increasing. Clearifying will ease the markets even if the tapering is announced early. So despite weaker numbers I raise my estimate sligthly.

In this report, https://reut.rs/3hYbT8v, the following quotes does leave things slightly open although it could be a strong indicator depending on unemployment and inflation; "Powell on Wednesday said officials could decide as soon as the next policy meeting in November that both of those standards have been met, based on what happens with the labor market and the broader economy, and make a decision on whether to taper."

"Last December, the Committee indicated that it would continue to increase its holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage‑backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward its maximum employment and price stability goals. Since then, the economy has made progress toward these goals. If progress continues broadly as expected, the Committee judges that a moderation in the pace of asset purchases may soon be warranted."
I believe this has to happen, but that's not the same as saying it will happen. I'll stay right with the crowd consensus.

Morgan Stanley: "With our year end target 10% below current levels, our view is clear: the mid-cycle transition will end with the rolling correction finally hitting the S&P 500." https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/ice-coming-morgan-stanley-warns-odds-destructive-20-correction-are-rising
The only situation where this would not happen is if a debt default forced the Treasury to act as an emergency buyer of debt to stabilize markets.

This is a good breakdown of where each voting member of the board stands. Also the article emphasizes that the market is more influenced by the Fed's stimulus than it is by fundamentals in a way never before seen. If the Fed taps the brakes even a little it will have an effect on the stock market which I don't think the Fed wants. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/fed-speaks-loudly-carries-feather
Down a bit as the Delta wave might cause the FED to think the economy isn't fully on the path to recovery

"The Federal Reserve will have to wind down its pandemic-era stimulus programme quickly and raise US interest rates in 2022 in response to higher inflation, according to a poll of leading academic economists for the Financial Times." See "Economists predict US interest rate rise in 2022" in the Financial Times.
Gjo has deleted my previos projections. Thus is crazy. I was at zero since inception. Switched to balance.
Raised from 70% to 85% given Powell's remarks and those of other Fed governors. However, it isn't a slam dunk given the lousy jobs report. They may wait until January, new year's market.

Lowering my prediction back down due to the avalanche of bad economic data. No change in labor force participation rate at last update. Increasing shortages across the economy, including building supplies, natural gas, fertilizer, and anything made from microchips. Consumer credit growth has slowed dramatically. The backlog at the ports is increasing, and our trade deficit has no sign of improving . The Evergrande land company in China is going through a $600 billion default, which could affect not only the Chinese economy but drag down the world as well.

James Bullard is one of the more hawkish members of the FOMC. He is strongly pushing for tapering of QE to begin soon. See https://www.ft.com/content/7c2fc0ce-e7c0-4083-92e8-e81d9235ab45 if you have an FT.com subscription; otherwise this gift link [https://on.ft.com/3naDdDX] is supposed to be good three times.
More and more I'm beginning to suspect that Powell didn't learn the lesson of the 1970s. Revising a bit downward from the 90% I was at.

The main factor in reducing QE bond buying is the labor market. With NFP numbers coming in below expectations yesterday (~250k vs 750k expected), I had to revise my forecast down. That being said, July numbers were revised up to over 1,000k. - https://finance.yahoo.com/news/august-jobs-report-nonfarm-payrolls-labor-department-coronavirus-194347179.html
"if the economy evolved broadly as anticipated, it could be appropriate to start reducing the pace of asset purchases this year."
+7, Powell is now acknowledging this is likely this year.
Noted Chairman Powell's recent comments.
At the virtual Jackson Hole conference Chairman Powell indicated that the inflation goal (sustainably >2%) has been met, and unemployment has been substantially reduced.
https://apnews.com/article/business-health-coronavirus-pandemic-economy-5540a3115d041e10327bfcad2be043e8 Seems likely, based on this and similar ruminations.
"KAPLAN SAYS FED HAS COMMUNICATED A TAPER IS COMING"
Waiting for Friday & Jackson Hole's report and b) wondering of Delta / unemployment will stay the FED's hand?

Increasing statements for tightening from Fed Governors lead me to believe this is now more probable even though conditions to drive it have not changed measurably, if anything inflation pressures are very slightly lower. The political aspects from the investor in crowd appear to be influencing some Fed participants, now speaking out more. End of the year might be tight in timing however, for me change in probability from a 50/50 coin flip to moderately "yes".

Stocks are currently up because of all the bad market data that has come out. Bad economic data means a greater chance that the FED is going to be more accommodating, which means better stock market. You know it's an artificial market when the market cares more about what stimulus is going to be given rather than actual fundamentals.

"Fed Signals Asset Purchases Likely to Slow this Year" "Minutes of their July 27-28 Fed meeting, released Wednesday, shed light on an emerging consensus to begin scaling back their $120 billion in monthly purchases of Treasury and mortgage securities at any of their three remaining policy meetings this year." https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-debated-timing-mechanics-of-stimulus-pullback-at-july-meeting-11629309648?mod=hp_lead_pos1
The market consensus is not until next year. The FED says it is data dependent, and I don't expect data to improve well enough to justify this happening.

This article dated August 11 in the Financial Times outlines recently stated opinions of several members of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors (BOG). Up 10 on the strong jobs report, the article linked by @jflom and the superforecaster analysis linked by @elifland. I'm not as confident as the superforecasters though, there's still a lot of jobs missing as shown in the labor force participation rate being way down, which could make the FED hesitant to start cutting back its purchases this year.

Increasing as it looks like the treasury may reduce debt issuance in Q4. Of course, Congress could always do more emergency spending, changing this. I believe much of the FED's motivation for QE is to cover treasuries the market doesn't want to buy https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/treasury-start-reducing-bond-auction-sizes-soon-november

Although I believe the superforecasters are overestimating the possibility of before September 23 given recent comments by chair Powell and potential threat of delta wave, I do agree that before December 15 is almost certain. In between the crowd forecast here of 70% (which feels intuitively about right to me, albeit with limited expertise/research) and the superforecasters, who are at 95% according to https://goodjudgment.io/superforecasts/ (!!)

Chairman Powell today said “I think we’re a ways away from having had substantial further progress toward the maximum employment goal. I would want to see some strong job numbers.” So will Powell hold off until the job numbers strengthen? People who know a lot more than me seem to think tapering will begin either in Q4/2021 or early 2022. The Fed has said it will give plenty of advance notice, so I'll stay with my overweight on "YES."

lowering based on today's vague comments by Powell “I think we’re some way away from having had substantial further progress toward the maximum employment goal.” : https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/28/fed-meeting-live-updates-watch-jerome-powell-speech.html

I think it's still 50%. Reason is they will be leery of upsetting the financial community. I do believe they will anounce that they will be doing it by Dec 16. If it happens, it will be very small amounts to start.
Will Mark to market rules change?

Will lower my estimate if the next meeting doesn't go as I'm expecting (with hints of tapering timelines), but I suspect they will at least announce tapering this year even if only to have it happen next year. According to this tapering could happen as soon as the end of this year: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/13/feds-mary-daly-says-tapering-of-bond-purchases-may-start-this-year.html
Revising up based on my reading on yesterday's meeting. The Fed will give a lot of notice, meaning they will probably need to announce long before the tapering is implemented.
The FED has stated they will not reduce QE until unemployment improves.
The month-to-month rates (0.6% March, 0.8% April, 0.6% May, 0.9% June) have totaled to 2.9% inflation in just four months.
Daly: "We'll be in a good position to taper at end of year, early next" Daly: "It is appropriate to start talking about tapering"

When they are forced to choose between the stock market and inflation they will always choose the stock market. Jerome Powell does not have the courage of Paul volcker. Even announcing a future date when tapering would begin would be a extremely contractive event that would crash the markets. Our country is addicted to easy money and it's only getting worse. The FED is trapped. I expect continued language about how inflation is good and this will offset the many years we had inflation below 2% and how they are adjusting their targets.

The chances are increasing however, not to point of highly "probable". In order for this to happen Americans will have to experience more inflationary pressures that affect daily life. Within the body politic the political factions are unlikely to unite to place pressure on the Fed to do this unless there is a public reaction. What is more likely is the Fed stops buying up mortgage debt. There is no reason to continue to do this. Therefore, I see it as 50/50 for now but increasing so 'yes', but offset by the pandemic slowdown with a large percentage refusing to be vaccinated. This means the virus 'prairie fire' will not be damped out. The tension is inflation vs virus.

Raising based on recent trend and fed partial reversal. I think they're in a calibrating mode now, and I think the next couple months numbers will determine whether or not they actually change course or hold steady. I think the key to take a look at is expectations anchoring. If they think expectations will become unanchored, they will almost certainly take action, however I think they would need to see things like TIPS breakevens blow out along with interest rate futures among others.

The 2 largest landlords in the U.S. are hiking rents by 10%+, home prices are 13%+ YoY, and homebuyer confidence has collapsed to numbers not seen in 30 years. I'd say it's time for the Fed to cease buying MBS.
Getting what you want messes you up.
I think with Core inflation running so hot, and new homeowners dropping out of the market that the Fed will need to cool things down by reducing QE.

After comments from Bullard, I could see a pull back specifically in the purchase of MBS. More importantly, the Fed only has to announce that it plans to before 16 December 2021 not actually enact it. Raising slightly.
looking more and more likely, but I'm a little bit less confident than the crowd

Mohamed El-Erian, a former CEO of PIMCO and prominent commentator on financial issues, recently wrote this opinion piece for Bloomberg. He argues that the Fed will have to begin tapering sooner rather than later to prevent a much bigger economic shock. See https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-06-15/fed-meeting-central-bank-needs-to-take-action-despite-its-framework?sref=x7nYEkiY.

"Investors believe that the US Federal Reserve may see rising inflation as a sign that it has to begin winding down its vast monetary stimulus program and weaning stock markets off years of ultra-low interest rates." https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/16/covid-outbreaks-in-chinese-ports-could-cause-global-goods-shortages

I see the likelihood as slightly higher than the 50/50 baseline crowd forecast. Reasons primarily stem from the ongoing strong recovery, the decreasing likelihood of inflation being transitory, and lowering quantitative easing being a friendlier alternative to raising fed funds rate.

Leaning towards more likely now, the FED seems willing to do this if the economy is strong this year and I think it will be. But the FED is also willing to let inflation run a bit higher so leaving lots of uncertainty.
Why continue it? Economy doesnt seem to need it. If signalling starts soon after a high inflation print seems likely.

The FED pretends to be vigilant in order to calm the market amid an inflation outbreak not seen in a decade, stating the job market may be tighter than it appears (clear indication their action will depend on the job market predominantly), and that the FED thinks about starting discussions about tapering the quantitative easing bond buying. Nevertheless, this assessment with a double reservation appears to be a nonsensical distraction from the fact that unemployment hasn't sunk as fast and as low as expected (and as may be necessary to fully realize growth potentials), and the FED will thus leave the monetary tap wide open to finance fiscal deficits.

Moving my prior 20% forecast to 50% more to reflect my level of uncertainty as opposed to my belief that it is 50% likely (this is merely because I believe at 50% the Brier score penalizes innaccuracy less). With reverse repos hitting their highest in 3 years, I think trouble is brewing which may prompt the Fed to reduce QE. https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/markets/why-demand-for-fed-e2-80-99s-reverse-repo-facility-is-surging-again/ar-AAKlg5X?ocid=BingNewsSearch
ticking up slightly on inflation concerns; thanks for the link @DNK89
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/19/fed-officials-said-rapid-progress-in-economy-could-lead-to-lowerng-asset-purchases.html
They might want to but they can't, the risk market has too much leverage and the risk market is the engine of the fed.

The Fed has been steadily increasing its balance sheets over the past year. And they have openly stated they are willing to allow the economy to "run hot" in the short term. This has been motivated by increasing employment numbers in response to Covid.

Yeah, this is highly likely. I mean, seriously, even a small cut qualifies, and we just had in April the highest month-to-month core inflation since 1981. Either the economy is going to come roaring back over the next few months and we can cut back on this, or we're headed for stagflation and it'll be absolute malpractice not to cut back on this.
Inflation at the wholesale level
QE started on march 15 2020 the current measure are in place since June 10 2020.

Powell has consistently signalled an institutional preference for a period of catch up inflation to bring mid to longer-term rolling trend to a cumulative 2% or a bit more. The lagging trend does not approach that level

With hindsight to the statistics available at https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/bst_recenttrends.htm the volume future asset purchases programs of the FED could take the same course as in the timeframe July 2009 through July 2010 in a post-Lehman Bros.-collapse financial world. The similarities are not obvious, but in a second thought, both crises concerned an external shock that hit a booming economy like a flash and the problem of both is "contagion", however, at a much larger scope with respect to unemployment and budget deficits in 2020 -22 and maybe a decade to come, and thus with a much larger upward slope in the FEDs balance sheet deterioration. Large deficit-funded spending programs/bills in the pipeline don't bode well for fiscal soundness, and even tax reform plans, if finally implemented, will likely not compensate fully for additional spending in a decade.

Overweighting Jerome Powell's statements that it will take more than a string of 1MM+ job reports for them to consider recovery in firm footing. Given that jobs deficit is what Powell tracks explictly and that is still 8.4MM below February, it will take ~8months of stellar jobs created, for Powell to consider taper. It is fair to trust Fed as Fed is extremely cautious about its own credibility.

Wisdom of the crowd as anchor (20%). Adjust uppwards because of Kaplans statements, (5%) he is more optimistic than other collegues, this means that he is the odd one out so i dont want to base too much on his statement. Eventhough vaccination could be done by then a lot of people in the states dont want to get vaccinated. However i belive this can change when they see better results in other countries and when they start to incentivese hevier for getting vaccines by giving vaccine passports to vaccinated people. (up 6%)
Otherwise would indicate failure of Creepy Joe's policy and leadership.

With the lack of foreign interest in USTs and the incredible sovereign debt racked up/racking up, it's unlikely the Fed could taper QE without causing massive funding issues for the government. And I expect there will be some amount of "testing the waters" with suggestions of tapering, before an actual announcement. Also, under what circumstances will strong demand for USTs (domestic or foreign) return, so the Fed CAN taper without causing a solvency problem? Real rates would need to be perceived as positive (which is hard to believe), and the stock market needs to show signs of weakening (very possible, especially if there are suggestions of tapering).
Be prepared.

December is a long time away so that makes the probability of this being higher as US economy would have almost fully recovered by then. Also QE raises the prospects of inflation (which is already higher than Fed target though "transitory" as per the fed). There are already murmurs of people within the fed questioning whether we should start tapering sooner. https://www.reuters.com/business/feds-kaplan-sees-financial-market-excesses-eyes-qe-taper-2021-04-30/

As per Gundlach, if interest rates exceed 225 bps (which I think is possible) the Fed will increase buying. I think the Fed should reduce MBS purchases because there don't appear to be any bottlenecks in the mortgage market (and rising rates might help re-establish equilibrium there). That said, I think the Fed HAS to continue buying all of the Treasuries being issued as foreign buyers reduce their holdings.

Reducing purchases is likely to come before raising rates, and I think if the US sees a strong 2021 there's a possibility that they slow down purchases by the end of the year. However unemployment will probably still be higher than optimal (though a lot better than it currently is) so it seems more likely to me that the FED would rather err on the side of a stronger economy than put a damper on things too soon, especially considering their recent shift to average inflation targeting.
Economic and Covid developments will offer the Fed an opportunity to begin tapering QE during 2021.
If anything, bond purchases will increase. There is decreasing demand for bonds at a time when the U.S is trying to sell more debt than ever before.
